raw_text:
Galloway targets 'New Labour' MP
 
 George Galloway is to stand against pro-Iraq war Labour MP Oona King at the next general election.
 
 Mr Galloway, who on Thursday won £150,000 in libel damages from the Daily Telegraph said he would contest Bethnal Green, in London, for Respect. The Glasgow Kelvin MP, who was expelled from Labour over his anti Iraq war stance, accused Ms King of being a "New Labour stooge". Ms King said she was "delighted" at the chance to take on Mr Galloway.
 
 Mr Galloway's current constituency is set to disappear under planned boundary changes in Scotland.
 
 The 50-year-old MP launched Respect, the Unity Coalition, in January along with 1,000 anti-war activists, and the Muslim Association of Britain. The party's declared aims are an end to the occupation of Iraq, the repeal of anti-union laws and the end of privatisation. Speaking from a cafe in Brick Lane, east London, Mr Galloway said he had accepted the party's invitation to stand with "great honour and pride".
 
 He added: "Here in this constituency of Bethnal Green and Bow there is a New Labour stooge MP. "A stooge who will sing any song, make any speech, do any dance, do anything she is told to by Tony Blair - irrespective of how her constituents are adversely affected or how strongly they feel to the contrary." Ms King has represented the constituency since 1997. She said: "I'm delighted I've been given the chance to finish him (Mr Galloway) off, and believe me I will. "I know many people around the country will be grateful, not least his constituents in Scotland who he has shamelessly abandoned." In June's European Parliament elections, Respect failed to gain enough votes for an MEP but did come first in Tower Hamlets borough, most of which is covered by the Commons constituency of Bethnal Green and Bow.
 
 A month later it gained a council seat in a by-election in St Dunstan's and Stepney Green ward, Tower Hamlets. Mr Galloway said that in next year's expected general election and local elections a year later, the party would "turn the East End of London into a fortress". Both the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats have chosen prospective parliamentary candidates for Bethnal Green and Bow from the Bangladeshi population, which makes up almost half the electorate. The Telegraph was sued for libel by Mr Galloway after the newspaper claimed he received money from Saddam Hussein's regime in Iraq. The newspaper said it was in the public interest to publish the claims, based on documents found in Baghdad. Mr Justice Eady said he was "obliged to compensate Mr Galloway... and to make an award for the purposes of restoring his reputation".
llama3.2:1b: George Galloway is running against Oona King in the 2023 general election as part of the Respect party, which aims to end the Iraq war occupation.
He previously represented the Glasgow Kelvin constituency but was expelled from Labour due to his anti-war stance.
The constituency will be redrawn under proposed boundary changes in Scotland, and Galloway has accepted an invitation to stand with "great honour".
llama3.2:3b: George Galloway to stand against Labour MP Oona King at next general election; Galloway will contest Bethnal Green seat for Respect party; Libel damages win included in speech.
gemma2:2b: George Galloway will stand against Oona King in the next general election as a candidate for Respect party.
Galloway claims King is a "New Labour stooge", and cites past boundary changes affecting his current constituency.

The party plans to turn Bethnal Green and Bow into a fortress in the 2005 general election and local elections, challenging both the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats who have chosen candidates from the Bangladeshi population.
Respect achieved some success in June's European Parliament elections but did not gain enough votes for an MEP.
Galloway has been awarded libel damages after The Telegraph published claims he received money from Saddam Hussein.
qwen2.5:0.5b: In a move aimed at challenging Oona King as the next Labour MP in Bethnal Green and Bow, Glasgow-based George Galloway is targeting the pro-Iraq War MP.
The 50-year-old MP launched Respect, Unity Coalition, and Muslim Association of Britain.
He was expelled from Labour over his anti-war stance after winning £150, 000 in libel damages from the Daily Telegraph.
Mr Galloway's current constituency is set to disappear under planned boundary changes in Scotland.
The 29-year-old MP launched Respect, the Unity Coalition, in January and received more than 1, 000 anti-war activists' support.
He said he accepted the party's invitation to stand with "great honour and pride."
Mr King represents the constituency since 1997.
She said she was "delighted" by the opportunity to finish Galloway off, believing many would be grateful.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Galloway aims to challenge anti-Iraq war Labour MP Oona King in Bethnal Green, London.
Galloway stands with Respect, Unity Coalition, and opposes Iraq occupation, labor laws, and privatization.
King is seeking re-election despite accusations of being a "New Labour stooge."
qwen2.5:3b: George Galloway will contest Bethnal Green constituency against Oona King, a pro-Iraq war Labour MP, at the next general election.
Galloway launched Respect, Unity Coalition in January with 1,000 anti-war activists; aims include ending Iraq occupation and privatisation repeal.
He accused King of being New Labour's puppet.
In June, Respect gained first place vote in Tower Hamlets but failed to win an MEP seat.
It has won a council seat since.
Galloway plans to 'turn the East End into a fortress' with expected general election and local elections next year.

Mr. Galloway will contest Bethnal Green, appealing to "Respect."
His current constituency, set to disappear due to Scotland's boundary changes, was expelled from Labour over anti-Iraq views.
Ms. King, since 1997, is glad she finished him off and expected major moves next year.
He aims to end Iraq occupation, repeal union laws, and privatisation.

Both Conservatives and Liberal Democrats pick Bethnal Green Constituents from the Democrat population, nearly half of the area.

tinyllama:1.1b: Summary: George Galloway, a pro-Iraq war Labour MP who won £150,000 in libel damages from The Daily Telegraph, plans to stand against anti-war UK Independence Party (UKIP) candidate Oona King at the next general election.

He will also contest Bethnal Green, in London, for Respect party, a coalition between UKIP and an opposition Labour Party constituency MP in the same area who was previously expelled from Labour over his anti-war stance.
The party aims to end the occupation of Iraq, repeal anti-union laws and end privatisations.

The party's declared aim is ending the "occupation" and repealing anti-union laws for the benefit of its constituents in Bethnal Green and Bow, a ward covered by the Constituency of Bethnal Green and Bow.
tinydolphin:1.1b: George Galloway, a respected Glasgow Kelvin MP, has decided to run against pro-Iraq war Labour MP Oona King in the next general election.

His decision is likely to affect the outcome of the contest, as it has garnered significant attention due to his staunch anti-war stance and his personal connections with residents in Bethnal Green and Bow.
Galloway's announcement comes just weeks after the Telegraph published claims that he had received funding from Saddam Hussein's regime in Iraq.
This accusation has made him a target for libel lawsuits, but Galloway is determined to stand up against the political machine and fight for his constituents.
The decision to run against King will also have an impact on local elections in the East End of London, where Respect has seen significant growth in recent years.
If Galloway is successful, he could turn the area into a fortress and further solidify his position as a voice for progressive change in British politics.

The 50-year-old MP has been criticized for choosing a marginal seat like Bethnal Green and Bow, but his decision to stand against King is a clear indication of his determination to make a difference in the lives of his constituents.
Despite facing challenges and setbacks, Galloway remains hopeful that his campaign will bring about change for the people he represents.
phi:2.7b: Respect party leader George Galloway will challenge pro-Iraq war Labour MP Oona King at the next election.
He won £150,000 in libel damages from the Daily Telegraph after the newspaper claimed he received money from Saddam Hussein's regime.

Mr Galloway, who was expelled from Labour over his anti-Iraq war stance, launched Respect with 1,000 anti-war activists and wants an end to the occupation of Iraq, repeal of anti-union laws, and the end of privatization.
He said he would contest Bethnal Green for the party and accused Ms King of being a "New Labour stooge."
Ms King, who has represented the constituency since 1997, said she was "delighted" at the chance to take on Mr Galloway.
Respect failed in the European Parliament elections but gained a council seat in a by-election in St Dunstan's and Stepney Green ward, Tower Hamlets.
The party will also contest next year's general election and local elections in 2021.

Mr Galloway won £150,000 in libel damages from the Daily Telegraph and said he would contest Bethnal Green for Respect.
He also stated that he had accepted an invitation to stand with "great honour and pride" for the party.

The party aims to end the occupation of Iraq, repeal anti-union laws, and end privatization.
In the European Parliament elections, Respect came first in Tower Hamlets borough but failed to gain an MEP seat.
Galloway said the party would turn the East End of London into a fortress in the upcoming elections.

granite3.1-dense:2b: George Galloway, expelled from Labour due to his anti-Iraq war stance, will challenge pro-Iraq war MP Oona King in Bethnal Green, London, at the next general election.

Galloway, who recently won £150,000 in libel damages against The Daily Telegraph for false claims he received funding from Saddam Hussein's regime, launched Respect, a party advocating for Iraq withdrawal, anti-union law repeal, and privatisation end.
King, representing the constituency since 1997, expressed delight at the prospect of defeating Galloway.
Galloway's current Scottish constituency will be dissolved due to boundary changes.
Respect performed well in Tower Hamlets borough and a St Dunstan's by-election but fell short of an MEP seat in June's European elections.
Both Conservatives and Liberal Democrats have selected prospective candidates from the predominantly Bangladeshi electorate.
